block.p: Accolades In this season of honors, figurative laurels bedeck Lena Horne, Bernice Johnson Reagon and Deborah Eisenberg. On Saturday night Ms. Horne will receive the ''Living the Dream'' mentor award of the Manhattan Country School, 7 East 96th Street, at its annual Rent Party, a jazz benefit for its scholarship fund. Ms. Reagon, professor of history at American University, curator emeritus at the Smithsonian National Museum of American History and a 1989 MacArthur fellow, has been named the first recipient of the Leeway Foundation Leeway Laurel. The award, in recognition of a woman's lifelong achievement in the arts, carries a prize of $100,000. Ms. Eisenberg, cited for her ''luminous fiction,'' is this year's winner of the $30,000 Rea Award for the short story.

It's Grand Guignol in grand style at 7 tonight at Avery Fisher Hall, where the New York Philharmonic, conducted by Andrew Litton, celebrates the composer-lyricist Stephen Sondheim's 70th birthday with a concert performance of his musical ''Sweeney Todd,'' directed by Lonny Price. George Hearn will portray the demon barber of Fleet Street, heading a cast that includes Patti LuPone as Mrs. Lovett and Audra McDonald, in her debut with the Philharmonic, as the Beggar Woman. Other roles are being taken by John Aler, Davis Gaines, Heidi Grant Murphy, Neil Patrick Harris, Stanford Olsen and Paul Plishka. The performances will be repeated tomorrow and Saturday nights at 8.

Where's the Boston Symphony Orchestra? Look at the foot of the Eiffel Tower at 9:30 tomorrow night. Under the auspices of the City of Paris, as part of its 2000 millennium celebration, and for an anticipated audience of 100,000, the ensemble is giving a free concert. Besides the orchestra, led by Seiji Ozawa, the participants include the tenor Andrea Bocelli, the Orchestre de Paris and a chorus of 600 adults and children.

At 7 tonight at the American Museum of Natural History, Dmitri Nabokov and George Plimpton will perform ''Dear Bunny, Dear Volodya: The Friendship and the Feud,'' a dramatic dialogue by Terry Quinn, based on the 30-year correspondence between Vladimir Nabokov (Dmitri's father) and Edmund Wilson. . . . He is the writer or co-writer of songs like ''Where Have All the Flowers Gone?'' and ''If I Had a Hammer.'' And he has championed the works of Huddie Ledbetter and Woody Guthrie. He is Pete Seeger, and on Saturday night at 8 he'll give a free concert in the Great Hall at Cooper Union, Seventh Street and Third Avenue in the East Village, as part of the New York Public Library for the Performing Arts series ''Treasures of the Music Division.''
